comment.author: 52325611@N05
comment._content: From The New York Times, November 25, 1914: "RECEPTIONS FOR DEBUTANTES. Miss Elise F. Rice a Debutante. Miss Elise French Rice, the second daughter of Mrs. William Lowe Rice, made her début yesterday afternoon at a tea dance, which Mrs. Rice gave for her in the rose room of the Plaza. Mrs. Rice, in white brocade and silver; Miss Mildred Gautier Rice, in turquoise velvet and silver, and the débutatne, in a white lace frock, looped up with little pink roses with a silver girdle, were assisted in receiving by the Misses Eugenia M. Fuller, Eva Mali, Eleanor W. Keep, Priscilla Peabody, Alice de Lamar, Marion Tiffany, Almy Gilford, Prudence Sterry, and Mary Frances Gilbert. Mrs. Rice will give a large dance for her débutante daughter on Dec. 14 at the Plaza." The New York Times, on 5th September 1923, published the announcement of Elise's engagement to marry Winfield S. Linn. Mr. Linn served honorably in the U.S. Navy during the First World War, as this citation indicates: "Winfield S. Linn The President of the United States of America takes pleasure in presenting the Navy Cross to Ensign Winfield S. Linn, United States Navy (Reserve Force), for distinguished service in the line of his profession as commanding officer, of the U.S.S. C-127, engaged in the important, exacting and hazardous duty of patrolling the waters of the War Zone and operating against enemy submarines during World War I."

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: the date on the negative, October 19,1923, indicates to me that this April,1915 picture, was cropped and reused in connection with her engagement.
